Seems to me now as the remembrance of an idle gaude,
Which in my childehood I did doat vpon:
And all the faith, the vertue of my heart,
The obiect and the pleasure of mine eye,
Is onely Helena. To her, my Lord,
Was I betroth’d, ere I ſee Hermia,
But like a ſickeneſſe did I loath this food,
But as in health, come to my naturall taste,
Now doe I wish it, loue it, long for it,
And will for euermore be true to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thes.
SPEECH.LINE: Faire Louers, you are fortunately met;
Of this discourse we ſhall heare more anon.
Egeus, I will ouer-beare your will;
For in the Temple, by and by with vs,
These couples ſhall eternally be knit.
And for the morning now is ſomething worne,
Our purpos’d hunting ſhall be ſet aside.
Away, with vs to Athens; three and three,
Wee'll hold a feast in great ſolemnitie.
Come Hippolita.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dem.
SPEECH.LINE: These things ſeeme ſmall & vndistinguishable,
Like farre off mountaines turned into Clouds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Her.
SPEECH.LINE: Me-thinks I ſee these things with parted eye,
When euery thing ſeemes double.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: So me-thinkes:
And I haue found Demetrius, like a iewell,
Mine owne, and not mine owne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dem.
SPEECH.LINE: It ſeemes to mee,
That yet we ſleepe, we dreame. Do not you thinke,
The Duke was heere, and bid vs follow him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Her.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea, and my Father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hel.
SPEECH.LINE: And Hippolita.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lys.
SPEECH.LINE: And he bid vs follow to the Temple.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dem.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then we are awake; lets follow him, and by the way let vs recount our dreames.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: When my cue comes, call me, and I will anſwer. My next is, mo’t faire Piramus. Hey ho. Peter Quince? Flute the bellowes-mender? Snout the tinker? Starue-ling? Gods my life! Stolne hence, and left me asleepe: I haue had a mo’t rare vision. I had a dreame, past the wit of man, to ſay, what dreame it was. Man is but an Aſſe, if he goe about to expound this dreame. Me-thought I was, there is no man can tell what. Me-thought I was, and me-thought I had. But man is but a patch’d foole, if he will offer to ſay, what me-thought I had. The eye of man hath not heard, the eare of man hath not ſeen, mans hand is not able to taste, his tongue to conceiue, nor his heart to report, what my dreame was. I will get Peter Quince to write a ballet of this dreame, it ſhall be called Bottomes Dreame, because it hath no bottome; and I will ſing it in the latter end of a play, before the Duke. Per-aduenture, to make it the more gracious, I ſhall ſing it at her death. Exit.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Quince, Flute, Thisbie, Snout, and Starueling.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Quin.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue you ſent to Bottomes house? Is he come home yet?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staru.
SPEECH.LINE: He cannot be heard of. Out of doubt hee is transported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: This.
SPEECH.LINE: If he come not, then the play is mar’d. It goes not forward, doth it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Quin.
SPEECH.LINE: It is not poſſible: you haue not a man in all
Athens, able to discharge Piramus but he.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: This.
SPEECH.LINE: No, hee hath ſimply the best wit of any handy-craft man in Athens.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Quin.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea, and the best person too, and hee is a very
Paramour, for a ſweet voyce.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: This.
SPEECH.LINE: You must ſay, Paragon. A Paramour is (God bleſſe vs) a thing of nought.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snug.
SPEECH.LINE: Masters, the Duke is comming from the Tem-ple, and there is two or three Lords & Ladies more mar-ried. If our ſport had gone forward, we had all bin made men.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: This.
SPEECH.LINE: O ſweet bully Bottome: thus hath he lost ſixe-pence a day, during his life; he could not haue ſcaped ſix-pence a day. And the Duke had not giuen him ſixpence a day for playing Piramus, Ile be hang’d. He would haue deserued it. Sixpence a day in Piramus, or nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bot.
SPEECH.LINE: Where are these Lads? Where are these hearts?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Quin.
SPEECH.LINE: Bottome, o mo’t couragious day! O mo’t hap-pie houre!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bot.
SPEECH.LINE: Masters, I am to discourse wonders; but ask me not what. For if I tell you, I am no true Athenian. I will tell you euery thing as it fell out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Let vs heare, ſweet Bottome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bot.
SPEECH.LINE: Not a word of me: all that I will tell you, is, that the Duke hath dined. Get your apparell together, good ſtrings to your beards, new ribbands to your pumps, meete presently at the Palace, euery man looke ore his part: for the ſhort and the long is, our play is preferred: In any case let Thisby haue cleane linnen: and let not him that playes the Lion, paire his nailes, for they ſhall hang out for the Lions clawes. And mo’t deare Actors, eate no Onions, nor Garlicke; for wee are to vtter ſweete breath, and I doe not doubt but to heare them ſay, it is a ſweet Comedy. No more words: away, go away.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Theseus, Hippolita, Egeus and his Lords.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hip.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis ſtrange my Theseus, y these louers ſpeake of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: The.
SPEECH.LINE: More ſtrange then true. I neuer may beleeue
These anticke fables, nor these Fairy toyes,
Louers and mad men haue ſuch ſeething braines,
Such ſhaping phantasies, that apprehend more
Then coole reason euer comprehends.
The Lunaticke, the Louer, and the Pœt,
Are of imagination all compact.
One ſees more diuels then vaste hell can hold;
That is the mad man. The Louer, all as franticke,
Sees Helens beauty in a brow of Egipt.
The Pœts eye in a fine frenzy rolling, doth glance
From heauen to earth, from earth to heauen.
And as imagination bodies forth the forms of things
Vnknowne; the Pœts pen turnes them to ſhapes,
And giues to aire nothing, a locall habitation,
And a name. Such tricks hath ſtrong imagination,
That if it would but apprehend ſome ioy,
It comprehends ſome bringer of that ioy.
Or in the night, imagining ſome feare,
Howe easie is a bush ſuppos’d a Beare?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hip.
SPEECH.LINE: But all the ſtorie of the night told ouer, And all their minds transfigur’d ſo together, More witneſſeth than fancies images, And growes to ſomething of great constancie; But howsœuer, ſtrange, and admirable.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter louers, Lysander, Demetrius, Hermia, and Helena

SPEECH.SPEAKER: The.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere come the louers, full of ioy and mirth:
Ioy, gentle friends, ioy and fresh dayes
Of loue accompany your hearts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lys.
SPEECH.LINE: More then to vs, waite in your royall walkes, your boord, your bed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: The.
SPEECH.LINE: Come now, what maskes, what dances ſhall we haue, To weare away this long age of three houres, Between our after ſupper, and bed-time? Where is our vsuall manager of mirth? What Reuels are in hand? Is there no play, To ease the anguish of a torturing houre? Call Egeus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ege.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere mighty Theseus.

SCENE.SPEECH: The. Say, what abridgement haue you for this eue-ning? _ What maske? What musicke? How ſhall we beguile The lazie time, if not with ſome delight?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ege.
SPEECH.LINE: There is a breefe how many ſports are rife:
Make choise of which your Highneſſe will ſee first.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lis.
SPEECH.LINE: The battell with the Centaurs to be ſung
By an Athenian Eunuch, to the Harpe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: The.
SPEECH.LINE: Wee'l none of that. That haue I told my Loue
In glory of my kinsman Hercules.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lis.
SPEECH.LINE: The riot of the tipsie Bachanals,
Tearing the Thracian ſinger, in their rage?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: The.
SPEECH.LINE: That is an old deuice, and it was plaid
When I from Thebes came last a Conqueror.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lis.
SPEECH.LINE: The thrice three Muses, mourning for the death of learning, late deceast in beggerie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: The.
SPEECH.LINE: That is ſome Satire keene and criticall,
Not ſorting with a nuptiall ceremonie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lis.
SPEECH.LINE: A tedious breefe Scene of yong Piramus,
And his loue Thisby; very tragicall mirth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: The.
SPEECH.LINE: Merry and tragicall? Tedious, and briefe? That is, hot ice, and wondrous ſtrange ſnow. How ſhall wee finde the concord of this discord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ege.
SPEECH.LINE: A play there is, my Lord, ſome ten words long,
Which is as breefe, as I haue knowne a play;
But by ten words, my Lord, it is too long;
Which makes it tedious. For in all the play,
There is not one word apt, one Player fitted.
And tragicall my noble Lord it is: for Piramus
Therein doth kill himselfe. Which when I ſaw
Rehearst, I must confeſſe, made mine eyes water:
But more merrie teares, the paſſion of loud laughter
Neuer ſhed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thes.
SPEECH.LINE: What are they that do play it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ege.
SPEECH.LINE: Hard handed men, that worke in Athens heere,
Which neuer labour’d in their mindes till now;
And now haue toyled their vnbreathed memories
With this ſame play, against your nuptiall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: The.
SPEECH.LINE: And we will heare it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hip.
SPEECH.LINE: No my noble Lord, it is not for you. I haue heard
It ouer, and it is nothing, nothing in the world;
Vnleſſ you can finde ſport in their intents,
Extreamely ſtretched, and cond with cruell paine,
To doe you ſeruice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thes.
SPEECH.LINE: I will heare that play. For neuer any thing
Can be amiſſe, when ſimpleneſſe and duty tender it.
Goe bring them in, and take your places, Ladies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hip.
SPEECH.LINE: I loue not to ſee wretchedneſſe orecharged;
And duty in his ſeruice perishing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thes.
SPEECH.LINE: Why gentle ſweet, you ſhall ſee no ſuch thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hip.
SPEECH.LINE: He ſaies, they can doe nothing in this kinde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thes.
SPEECH.LINE: The kinder we, to giue them thanks for nothing
Our ſport ſhall be, to take what they mistake;
And what poore duty cannot doe, noble respect
Takes it in might, not merit.
Where I haue come, great Clearkes haue purposed
To greete me with premeditated welcomes;
Where I haue ſeene them ſhiuer and looke pale,
Make periods in the midst of ſentences,
Throttle their practiz’d accent in their feares,
And in conclusion, dumbly haue broke off,
Not paying me a welcome. Trust me ſweete,
Out of this ſilence yet, I pickt a welcome:
And in the modesty of fearefull duty,
I read as much, as from the ratling tongue
Of ſaucy and audacious eloquence.
Loue therefore, and tongue-tide ſimplicity,
In least, ſpeake mo’t, to my capacity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Egeus.
SPEECH.LINE: So please your Grace, the Prologue is addrest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke
SPEECH.LINE: Let him approach.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: If we offend, it is with our good will.
That you ſhould thinke, we come not to offend,
But with good will. To ſhew our ſimple ſkill,
That is the true beginning of our end.
Consider then, we come but in despight.
We do not come, as minding to content you,
Our true intent is. All for your delight,
We are not heere. That you ſhould here repent you,
The Actors are at hand; and by their ſhow,
You ſhall know all, that you are like to know.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thes.
SPEECH.LINE: This fellow doth not ſtand vpon points.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lys.
SPEECH.LINE: He hath rid his Prologue, like a rough Colt: he knowes not the ſtop. A good morall my lord. it is not enough to ſpeake, but to ſpeake true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hip.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed hee hath plaid on his Prologue, like a childe on a Recorder, a ſound, but not in gouernment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thes.
SPEECH.LINE: His ſpeech was like a tangled chaine: nothing impaired, but all disordered. Who is next?

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Tawyer with a Trumpet before them.
Enter Pyramus and Thisby, Wall, Moone-shine, and Lyon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prol.
SPEECH.LINE: Gentles, perchance you wonder at this ſhow,
But wonder on, till truth make all things plaine.
This man is Piramus, if you would know;
This beauteous Lady, Thisby is certaine.
This man, with lyme and rough-cast, doth present
Wall, that vile wall, which did these louers ſunder:
And through walls chink (poor ſoules) they are content
To whisper. At the which, let no man wonder.
This man, with Lanthorne, dog, and bush of thorne,
Presenteth moone-shine. For if you will know,
By moone-shine did these Louers thinke no ſcorne
To meet at Ninus toombe, there, there to woœ:
This grizly beast (which Lyon hight by name)
The trusty Thisby, comming first by night,
Did ſcarre away, or rather did affright:
And as ſhe fled, her mantle ſhe did fall;
Which Lyon vile with bloody mouth did ſtaine.
Anon comes Piramus, ſweet youth and tall,
And findes his Thisbies Mantle ſlaine;
Whereat, with blade, with bloody blamefull blade,
He brauely broacht his boiling bloudy breast,
And Thisby, tarrying in Mulberry ſhade,
His dagger drew, and died. For all the rest,
Let Lyon, Moone-shine, Wall, and Louers twaine,
At large discourse, while here they doe remaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thes.
SPEECH.LINE: I wonder if the Lion be to ſpeake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Deme.
SPEECH.LINE: No wonder, my Lord: one Lion may, when many Aſſes doe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wall.
SPEECH.LINE: In this ſame Interlude, it doth befall,
That I, one Snowt (by name) present a wall:
And ſuch a wall, as I would haue you thinke,
That had in it a crannied hole or chinke:
Through which the Louers, Piramus and Thisbie
Did whisper often, very ſecretly.
This loame, this rough-cast, and this ſtone doth ſhew,
That I am that ſame Wall; the truth is ſo.
And this the cranny is, right and ſinister,
Through which the fearfull Louers are to whisper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thes.
SPEECH.LINE: Would you desire Lime and Haire to ſpeake better?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Deme.
SPEECH.LINE: It is the wittiest partition, that euer I heard discourse, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thes.
SPEECH.LINE: Pyramus drawes neere the Wall, ſilence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pir.
SPEECH.LINE: O grim lookt night, o night with hue ſo blacke,
O night, which euer art, when day is not:
O night, o night, alacke, alacke, alacke,
I feare my Thisbies promise is forgot.
And thou o wall, thou ſweet and louely wall,
That ſtands between her fathers ground and mine,
Thou wall, o Wall, o ſweet and louely wall,
Shew me thy chinke, to blinke through with mine eine.
Thankes courteous wall. Ioue ſhield thee well for this.
But what ſee I? No Thisbie doe I ſee.
O wicked wall, through whom I ſee no bliſſe,
Curst be thy ſtones for thus deceiuing mee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thes.
SPEECH.LINE: The wall me-thinkes being ſensible, ſhould curse againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pir.
SPEECH.LINE: No in truth ſir, he ſhould not. Deceiuing me,
Is Thisbies cue; ſhe is to enter, and I am to ſpy
Her through the wall. You ſhall ſee it will fall.
Pat as I told you; yonder ſhe comes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: This.
SPEECH.LINE: O wall, full often hast thou heard my mones,
For parting my faire Piramus, and me
My cherry lips haue often kist thy ſtones;
Thy ſtones with Lime and Haire knit vp in thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pyra.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſee a voyce; now will I to the chinke,
To ſpy and I can heare my Thisbies face. Thisbie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: This.
SPEECH.LINE: My Loue thou art, my Loue I thinke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pir.
SPEECH.LINE: Thinke what thou wilt, I am thy Louers grace,
And like Limander am I trusty ſtill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: This.
SPEECH.LINE: And like Helen till the Fates me kill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pir.
SPEECH.LINE: Not Shafalus to Procrus was ſo true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: This.
SPEECH.LINE: As Shafalus to Procrus, I to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pir.
SPEECH.LINE: O kiſſe me through the hole of this vile wall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: This.
SPEECH.LINE: I kiſſe the wals hole, not your lips at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pir.
SPEECH.LINE: Wilt thou at Ninnies tombe meete me ſtraight way?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: This.
SPEECH.LINE: Tide life, tide death, I come without delay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wall.
SPEECH.LINE: Thus haue I Wall, my part discharged ſo;
And being done, thus Wall away doth go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: Now is the morall downe between the two
Neighbours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dem.
SPEECH.LINE: No remedie my Lord, when Wals are ſo wil-full, to heare without warning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dut.
SPEECH.LINE: This is the ſilliest ſtuffe that ere I heard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: The best in this kind are but ſhadowes, and the worst are no worse, if imagination amend them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dut.
SPEECH.LINE: It must be your imagination then, & not theirs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: If wee imagine no worse of them then they of themselues, they may paſſe for excellent men. Here com two noble beasts, in a man and a Lion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lyon.
SPEECH.LINE: You Ladies, you (whose gentle harts do feare
The ſmallest monstrous mouse that creepes on floore)
May now perchance, both quake and tremble heere,
When Lion rough in wildest rage doth roare.
Then know that I, one Snug the Ioyner am
A Lion fell, nor else no Lions dam:
For if I ſhould as Lion come in ſtrife
Into this place, 'twere pittie of my life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: A verie gentle beast, and of good conscience.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dem.
SPEECH.LINE: The verie best at a beast, my Lord, y ere I ſaw.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lis.
SPEECH.LINE: This Lion is a verie Fox for his valor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: True, and a Goose for his discretion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dem.
SPEECH.LINE: Not ſo my Lord: for his valor cannot carrie his discretion, and the fox carries the Goose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: His discretion I am ſure cannot carrie his valor: for the Goose carries not the Fox. It is well; leaue it to his discretion, and let vs hearken to the Moone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moone.
SPEECH.LINE: This Lanthorne doth the horned Moone pre-sent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: De.
SPEECH.LINE: He ſhould haue worne the hornes on his head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: Hee is no crescent, and his hornes are inuisible, within the circumference.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moon.
SPEECH.LINE: This lanthorne doth the horned Moone pre-sent:
My ſelfe, the man i'th Moone doth ſeeme to be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: This is the greatest error of all the rest; the man Should be put into the Lanthorne. How is it els the man i'th Moone?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dem.
SPEECH.LINE: He dares not come there for the candle.
For you ſee, it is already in ſnuffe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dut.
SPEECH.LINE: I am wearie of this Moone; would he would change.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: It appeares by his ſmal light of discretion, that he is in the wane: but yet in courtesie, in all reason, we must ſtay the time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lys.
SPEECH.LINE: Proceed Moone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moon.
SPEECH.LINE: All that I haue to ſay, is to tell you, that the Lanthorne is the Moone; I, the man in the Moone; this thorne bush; my thorne bush; and this dog, my dog.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dem.
SPEECH.LINE: Why all these ſhould be in the Lanthorne: for they are in the Moone. But ſilence, heere comes Thisby.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: This.
SPEECH.LINE: This is old Ninnies tombe: where is my loue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lyon.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: The Lion roares, Thisby runs off.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dem.
SPEECH.LINE: Well roar’d Lion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: Well run Thisby.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dut.
SPEECH.LINE: Well ſhone Moone.
Truly the Moone ſhines with a good grace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: Wel mouz’d Lion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dem.
SPEECH.LINE: And then came Piramus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lys.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſo the Lion vanisht.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pyr.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet Moone, I thank thee for thy ſunny beames,
I thanke thee Moone, for ſhining now ſo bright:
For by thy gracious, golden, glittering beames,
I trust to taste of truest Thisbies ſight.
But ſtay: O ſpight! but marke, poore Knight,
What dreadful dole is heere?
Eyes do you ſee! How can it be!
O dainty Ducke: O Deere!
Thy mantle good; what ſtaind with blood!
Approch you furies fell:
O Fates! come, come: Cut thred and thrum,
Quaile, crush, conclude, and quell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: This paſſion, and the death of a deare friend,
Would go neere to make a man looke ſad.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dut.
SPEECH.LINE: Beshrew my heart, but I pittie the man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pir.
SPEECH.LINE: O wherefore Nature, did'st thou Lions frame?
Since lion vilde hath heere deflour’d my deere:
Which is: no, no, which was the fairest Dame
That liu’d, that lou’d, that like’d, that look’d with cheere.
Come teares, confound: Out ſword, and wound
The pap of Piramus:
I, that left pap, where heart doth hop;
Thus dye I, thus, thus, thus.
Now am I dead, now am I fled, my ſoule is in the ſky,
Tongue lose thy light, Moone take thy flight,
Now dye, dye, dye, dye, dye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dem.
SPEECH.LINE: No Die, but an ace for him; for he is but one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lis.
SPEECH.LINE: Leſſe then an ace man. For he is dead, he is no-thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: With the helpe of a Surgeon, he might yet reco-uer, and proue an Aſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dut.
SPEECH.LINE: How chance Moone-shine is gone before?
Thisby comes backe, and findes her Louer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: She wil finde him by ſtarre-light.
Heere ſhe comes, and her paſſion ends the play.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dut.
SPEECH.LINE: Me thinkes ſhee ſhould not vse a long one for ſuch a Piramus: I hope ſhe will be breefe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dem.
SPEECH.LINE: A Moth wil turne the ballance, which Piramus which Thisby is the better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lys.
SPEECH.LINE: She hath ſpyed him already, with those ſweete eyes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dem.
SPEECH.LINE: And thus ſhe meanes, videlicit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: This.
SPEECH.LINE: Asleepe my Loue? What, dead my Doue? O Piramus arise: Speake, ſpeake. Quite dumbe? Dead, dead? A tombe Must couer thy ſweet eyes. These Lilly Lips, this cherry nose, These yellow Cowslip cheekes Are gone, are gone: Louers make mone: His eyes were greene as Leekes. O Sisters three, come, come to mee, With hands as pale as Milke, Lay them in gore, ſince you haue ſhore with ſheeres, his thred of ſilke. Tongue not a word: Come trusty ſword: Come blade, my brest imbrue: And farwell friends, thus Thisbie ends; Adieu, adieu, adieu.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Moone-shine & Lion are left to burie the dead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Deme.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and Wall too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bot.
SPEECH.LINE: No, I aſſure you, the wall is downe, that parted their Fathers. Will it please you to ſee the Epilogue, or to heare a Bergomask dance, betweene two of our com-pany?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: No Epilogue, I pray you; for your play needs no excuse. Neuer excuse; for when the plaiers are all dead, there need none to be blamed. Marry, if hee that writ it had plaid Piramus, and hung himselfe in Thisbies garter, it would haue beene a fine Tragedy: and ſo it is truely, and very notably discharg’d. but come, your Burgomaske; let your Epilogue alone. The iron tongue of midnight hath told twelue. Louers to bed, ‘tis almost Fairy time. I feare we ſhall out-sleepe the comming morne, As much as we this night haue ouer-watcht. This palpable groſſe play hath well beguil’d The heauy gate of night. Sweet friends to bed. A fortnight hold we this ſolemnity. In nightly Reuels; and new iollitie. Exeunt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puck.
SPEECH.LINE: Now the hungry Lyons rores,
And the Wolfe beholds the Moone:
Whilest the heauy ploughman ſnores,
All with weary taske fore-done.
Now the wasted brands doe glow,
Whil'st the ſcritch-owle, ſcritching loud,
Puts the wretch that lies in wœ,
In remembrance of a ſhrowd.
Now it is the time of night,
That the graues, all gaping wide,
Euery one lets forth his ſpright,
In the Church-way paths to glide,
And we Fairies, that do runne,
By the triple Hecates teame,
From the presence of the Sunne,
Following darkeneſſe like a dreame,
Now are frollicke; not a Mouse
Shall disturbe this hallowed house.
I am ſent with broome before,
To ſweep the dust behinde the doore.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter King and Queene of Fairies, with their traine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ob.
SPEECH.LINE: Through the house giue glimmering light,
By the dead and drowsie fier,
Euerie Elfe and Fairie ſpright,
Hop as light as bird from brier,
And this Ditty after me, ſing and dance it trippinglie,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tita.
SPEECH.LINE: First rehearse this ſong by roate, To each word a warbling note. Hand in hand, with Fairie grace, Will we ſing and bleſſe this place.

Now vntill the breake of day, Through this house each Fairy ſtray. To the best Bride-bed will we, Which by vs ſhall bleſſed be: And the iſſue there create, Euer ſhall be fortunate: So ſhall all the couples three, Euer true in louing be: And the blots of Natures hand, Shall not in their iſſue ſtand. Neuer mole, harelip, nor ſcarre, nor mark prodigious, ſuch as are Despised in Natiuitie, Shall vpon their children be. With this field dew consecrate, Euery Fairy take his gate, And each ſeuerall chamber bleſſe, Through this Pallace with ſweet peace, Euer ſhall in ſafety rest. And the owner of it blest. Trip away, make no ſtay; Meet me all by breake of day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robin.
SPEECH.LINE: If we ſhadowes haue offended,
Thinke but this (and all is mended)
That you haue but ſlumbred heere,
While these Visions did appeare.
And this weake and idle theame,
No more yeelding but a dreame,
Gentles, doe not reprehend.
If you pardon, we will mend.
And as I am an honeſt Pucke,
If we haue vnearned lucke,
Now to ſcape the Serpents tongue,
We will make amends ere long:
Else the Pucke a lyar call.
So good night vnto you all.
Giue me your hands, if we be friends,
And Robin ſhall restore amends.
